title: Illinois Football’s Offense is Spending a lot More Time on the Field
text:
To start I loaded the required libraries for this project.


Code
library(tidyverse)


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Code
library(scales)



Attaching package: 'scales'

The following object is masked from 'package:purrr':

    discard

The following object is masked from 'package:readr':

    col_factor


Then, I’ll load in both libraries.


Code
twentyfour_plays <- read_csv("https://dwillis.github.io/sports-data-files/footballlogs24.csv")


Rows: 1717 Columns: 79
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr  (11): Location, Opponent, Result, OT, Bowl.x, TeamURL, Outcome, Bowl.y,...
dbl  (64): Rk, Gtm, Points, PointsOpp, PassCmp, PassAtt, PassPct, PassYds, P...
lgl   (3): Score, TeamScore, OpponentScore
date  (1): Date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


Code
twentyfive_plays <- read_csv("https://thescoop.org/sports-data-files/footballlogs25.csv")


Rows: 711 Columns: 77
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr   (9): Location, Opponent, Result, OT, TeamURL, Outcome, Team, Conferenc...
dbl  (64): Rk, Gtm, Points, PointsOpp, PassCmp, PassAtt, PassPct, PassYds, P...
lgl   (3): Score, TeamScore, OpponentScore
date  (1): Date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


Then I had to isolate our Big Ten teams, and add a column that has the total plays for each team in the conference.


Code
twentyfour_btn <- twentyfour_plays |> group_by(TeamFull) |> filter(Conference == "Big Ten Conference") |> mutate(allplays = sum(TotalPlays))

twentyfive_btn <- twentyfive_plays |> group_by(TeamFull) |> filter (Conference == "Big Ten Conference") |>mutate(allplays =sum(TotalPlays))  


Then I used ggplot to create my first bar graph of the 2025 data, and give it the proper labels.


Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(
    data=twentyfour_btn, 
    aes( 
      x=reorder (TeamFull, TotalPlays), 
        weight=TotalPlays
  )
  ) +
scale_y_continuous(labels=comma) + 
  labs(
    title="2024 Big Ten Plays by Team", 
    x="School", 
    y="Total Plays Ran"
) +
    theme_minimal() + 
  coord_flip()









I copy and pasted that code, but plugged in the 2025 data.


Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(
    data=twentyfive_btn, 
    aes( 
      x=reorder (TeamFull, TotalPlays), 
        weight=TotalPlays
  )
  ) +
scale_y_continuous(labels=comma) + 
  labs(
    title="2025 Big Ten Plays by Team", 
    x="School", 
    y="Total Plays Ran"
) +
    theme_minimal() + 
  coord_flip()









The biggest problem I ran into in this data examination is that I could not figure out how to get a plays per game column which would have made for a better comparison point between the years. From what I do have though, the biggest takeaway is how far Illinois is ahead of their peers in total plays, and how relatively far back Ohio State is. I think this makes it clear that the number of plays your running is not predictive of how good of a team you are given how good Ohio State has been this year.
